title: U.S. House and Senate Republicans Agree on Combined Budget
authors: Nick Timiraos, Kristina Peterson, Nick.Timiraos Wsj.Com
content:
WASHINGTON—Senate and House Republicans reached agreement Wednesday on a combined budget , setting up votes for the first spending blueprint agreed to by both chambers of Congress since 2009 .
The proposal would boost military spending while outlining a path to end deficits over the coming decade by cutting some $ 5 trillion in spending . The agreement is unlikely to receive any votes from Democrats , who have said it relies too heavily on sharp cuts to federal programs without raising revenue .
The agreement came after Sen. Bob Corker ( R. , Tenn. ) dropped his objections to certain spending maneuvers that he had described as gimmicks on Tuesday . The row over how to ease the pinch of across-the-board curbs known as the sequester , which Congress agreed to four years ago , is likely to resurface as lawmakers turn to approving spending bills later this year .

The president doesn ’ t sign the budget resolution , which is instead used to set overall spending levels that guide appropriators when they write those spending bills . President Barack Obama has said he won ’ t accept bills that keep in place the sequester , and he won ’ t support those that raise only defense spending , but not nondefense spending .
The House and Senate passed separate budget blueprints last month , and negotiators had been working to reconcile the two proposals . If passed by both chambers , the joint resolution would be the first by a Republican-controlled Congress since 2005 .
The House is expected to vote on the budget on Friday . Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell ( R. , Ky. ) said he hoped the Senate could vote on the measure this week .
Republicans have faced doubts over whether they could unite an unwieldy caucus that includes fiscal hawks dedicated to curbing deficits and defense hawks eager to boost national security funding . The final agreement was built on a compromise that isn ’ t seen as ideal by either side . It would boost military spending by using a separate war fund that isn ’ t subject to the sequester .
If it passes , the budget resolution will also unlock a procedural tool that Republicans say they will use to send the White House a repeal of Mr. Obama ’ s health-care law . That tool , known as “ reconciliation , ” allows legislation to pass Congress with a simple majority . Republicans control 54 of 100 seats in the Senate , where most bills require 60 votes to avoid procedural hurdles .
Republicans have so far deferred messier intraparty fiscal battles , such as over how significantly to overhaul entitlements , to complete an agreement that frees them to use reconciliation .
Some Republicans had questioned the merits of using the procedural shortcut to pass legislation Mr. Obama is sure to veto . But some said they see an opening when the Supreme Court decides , likely in late June , whether to strike down subsidies received by millions of Americans who purchased health insurance through a federally run exchange .
” That gives us an opportunity to use reconciliation to offer an alternative , ” said Rep. Richard Hudson ( R. , N.C. ) “ I ’ m not going to bet my farm that he ’ ll sign a bill repealing his signature legislation , but certainly getting it to his desk is better than the House sending bills over to the Senate that never get considered , ” he said .
House GOP lawmakers said there appeared to be few new objections to the latest version of the budget , which cleared the House only after leaders brokered the compromise over defense spending .
” Our belief is that if you voted for the budget that passed a few weeks ago , there ’ s really no reason why you couldn ’ t support this one , ” said Rep. Luke Messer of Indiana , a member of House GOP leadership .
Still , the budget process exposed fissures within the GOP over how to deal with the sequester , which is set in law . Even as Republicans ironed out their proposal to balance the budget over the coming decade , the bigger fights have centered around how to boost spending in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 .
Spending bills will need Democratic support in the Senate to avoid a filibuster , raising the prospect of a bipartisan agreement to roll back the sequester by finding offsetting cuts elsewhere . Alternately , the government could face another bout of gridlock this fall , with the prospect of a federal shutdown if both parties can ’ t reach an agreement over how to fund the government .
